chapter.title: Planning for &sled;
chapter.para: This chapter is addressed mainly to corporate system administrators who face the task of having to deploy &sledreg; at their site. Rolling out &sled; to an entire site should involve careful planning and consideration of the following questions:

varlistentry.term: For which purpose will the &sled; workstations be used?

listitem.para: Determine the purpose for which &sled; should be used and make sure that hardware and software with the ability to match these requirements are used. Consider testing your setup on a single machine before rolling it out to the entire site.

varlistentry.term: How many workstations should be installed?

listitem.para: Determine the scope of your deployment of &sled;. Depending on the number of installations planned, consider different approaches to the installation or even a mass installation using &sle;s unique &ay; or &kiwi; technology. For more information about this subject, refer to .

varlistentry.term: How do you get software updates for your deployment?

listitem.para: All patches provided by Novell for your product are available for download to registered users. Register and find the patch support database at .

varlistentry.term: Do you need help for your local deployment?

listitem.para: Novell provides training, support, and consulting for all topics pertaining to &sled;. Find more information about this at .

sect1.title: Hardware Requirements
sect1.para: For a standard installation of &sled;, including the desktop environment and a wealth of applications, the following configuration is recommended:

listitem.para: Intel Pentium IV, 2.4 GHz or higher or any AMD64 or &intel64; processor
3 GB of available disk space or more

sect1.title: Reasons to Use &sled;
sect1.para: Let the following items guide you in your selection of &sled; and determining the purpose of the installed systems:

listitem.para: &sled;'s broad offer of software makes it appeal to both professional users in a corporate environment and to home users or users in smaller networks.

&sled; comes with two enterprise-ready desktop environments, GNOME and KDE. Both enable users to comfortably adjust to a Linux system while maintaining their efficiency and productivity. To explore the desktops in detail, refer to the and the .
With the NetworkManager technology fully integrated into &sled; and its two desktop environments, mobile users will enjoy the freedom of easily joining and switching wired and wireless networks.
&sled; was designed to be a versatile network citizen. It cooperates with various different network types:

formalpara.title: Pure Linux Networks
formalpara.para: &sled; is a complete Linux client and supports all the protocols used in traditional Linux and Unix* environments. It integrates well with networks consisting of other &suselinux; or &sle; machines. LDAP, NIS, and local authentication are supported.

formalpara.title: Windows Networks
formalpara.para: &sled; supports Active Directory as an authentication source. It offers you all the advantages of a secure and stable Linux operating system plus convenient interaction with other Windows clients, as well as the means to manipulate your Windows user data from a Linux client. Explore this feature in detail in .
